docs.lead_paragraph: I am an American man and color and texture are not my strong suits.

docs.lead_paragraph: The onslaught of television commercials opposing health care legislation has prompted a liberal advocacy group and two labor unions to begin a $1.7 million advertising campaign in favor of the overhaul. The commercials, being shown on both cable and broadcast stations in 13 Congressional districts, try to buck up 12 Democrats and the lone Republican who voted in favor of health care legislation when it passed the House on Nov. 7.
docs.abstract: Americans United for Change, American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees and Service Employees International Union, countering onslaught of television commercials by US Chamber of Commerce and affiliated business organizations, begins $1.7 million ad campaign in favor of health care overhaul; photo (S)
docs.snippet: The onslaught of television commercials opposing  health care legislation has prompted a liberal advocacy group and two labor unions to begin a $1.7 million advertising campaign in favor of the  overhaul.     The commercials, being shown on both...

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: AMERICAN FEDERATION OF STATE, COUNTY AND MUNICIPAL EMPLOYEES

docs.lead_paragraph: Revised guidelines from an influential panel of medical experts suggest that women under age 50 forgo annual mammograms. Conservatives were quick to cite the new recommendations as an example of hazardous government intrusion into health care, and many readers agreed. Following are a sampling of comments: Here in a single capsule-sized dose is the reason health care costs are skyrocketing: No one is willing to accept anything short of the Cadillac standard of health care, even when a Ford is perfectly adequate to get you where you want to go. Donnolo Their agenda at the outset was one of cost-cutting, making more money for the insurance companies in the short term, and not patient care. They totally ignored a large body of evidence that contradicts their position. Marco77 It's all about cost first, quality second. In this health care debate, you get to pick your poison, but both pills are bitter. Bill My first mammogram, at the age of 40, showed I had ductal carcinoma in situ. Surgery followed. Five years later, I had invasive cancer, a far more aggressive and dangerous disease. It is unthinkable that mammograms should be withheld until the age of 50. It is also unforgivable that a remote task force could propose such a disturbing and alarming suggestion. cjm What about screening for prostate cancer? Oh, of course, men are better able to deal with the trauma of false positives. Fragile women must be shielded from this awful fate, even at the risk of their lives. Silly me. Robinson
docs.abstract: Sampling of reader comments about revised guidelines on mammograms; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In seeking to fend off a major revolt by supporters of abortion rights, Democratic leaders in the Senate have infuriated abortion opponents with their new version of health care legislation.
docs.abstract: In seeking to fend off a major revolt by supporters of abortion rights, Democratic leaders in the Senate have infuriated abortion opponents with their new version of health care legislation.
docs.snippet: In seeking to fend off a major revolt by supporters of abortion rights, Democratic leaders in the Senate have infuriated abortion opponents with their new version of health care legislation.

docs.lead_paragraph: My Thursday column looks back at the arguments against Medicare and, before that, Social Security -- and notes that they were the same as the arguments today against universal health care.
docs.abstract: The debate over health reform this year is an echo of the battles over Medicare and Social Security, generations ago. The same tired arguments that were used against them are being revived to oppose universal health care today.
docs.snippet: The debate over health reform this year is an echo of the battles over Medicare and Social Security, generations ago. The same tired arguments that were used against them are being revived to oppose universal health care today.

docs.lead_paragraph: AARP, the association representing millions of retired Americans, offered a qualified endorsement on Wednesday night of the new health care bill produced by Senate Democratic leaders.

headline.main: Mixed Reviews on Senate Bill From AARP

docs.abstract: The AARP issues a qualified endorsement of the Senate health care proposal on Wednesday night.
docs.snippet: The AARP issues a qualified endorsement of the Senate health care proposal on Wednesday night.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Harry Reid's health care bill included an array of new provisions that are being scrutinized Wednesday night, but one particular tax proposal in particular already has attracted a buzz - a 5 percent levy on elective cosmetic procedures that was quickly dubbed the "botax."

headline.main: Reid Proposes a 5% Tax on Cosmetic Surgery

docs.abstract: A possible new flashpoint in the health care debate: the 'botax.'
docs.snippet: A possible new flashpoint in the health care debate: the 'botax.'

docs.lead_paragraph: First, a correction. The concluding point in my earlier post is wrong: The House health care bill would not, in fact, effectively tax all 18 million of the remaining uninsured to pay for coverage for the other 36 million, because some percentage of that 18 million - in the draft of the Senate bill, it's anyone who couldn't find a health care plan costing less than 8 percent of income; in the House bill it's still unspecified - would be eligible for a "hardship waiver" exempting them from paying the fine if they can't afford coverage. And this exemption makes the House bill a better deal for the uninsured than I suggested.
docs.abstract: A correction, and further discussion of what health care reform will cost the uninsured.
docs.snippet: A correction, and further discussion of what health care reform will cost the uninsured.

docs.lead_paragraph: A group of female House Republicans used the upset over new guidelines on breast cancer screening issued by an advisory panel earlier this week to highlight what they view as the dangers of government-administered health care and the Democrats' bill to revamp the system.
docs.abstract: A group of Republican lawmakers on Capitol Hill used the upset over new recommendations on breast cancer screenings as an example of government-run health care gone awry.
docs.snippet: A group of Republican lawmakers on Capitol Hill used the upset over new recommendations on breast cancer screenings as an example of government-run health care gone awry.

docs.lead_paragraph: Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius on Wednesday afternoon issued a strong statement intended to put distance between federal policy and an influential panel's recommendations that most women should start regular breast cancer screening at age 50, not 40.

headline.main: Sebelius on Mammograms: Don't Change What You're Doing

docs.abstract: The head of the Health and Human Services department cautions that a panel's recommendations on mammograms don't dictate federal policy and won't change federal coverage.
docs.snippet: The head of the Health and Human Services department cautions that a panel's recommendations on mammograms don't dictate federal policy and won't change federal coverage.
